The Catholic Archbishop of Jos, in central Nigeria, has accused the West of ignoring the threat of the militant Islamist group, Boko Haram.He said the international community had to show the same spirit and resolve it had done after the attacks in France.

Thoughts on it OT ? Should west get involved in eliminating Boko Haram once and for all ? Hillary Clinton and many west politicians previously condemned Boko Haram actions as kidnapping 200 school girls :)

No one cares about Africa, unfortunately. We saw it with Rwanda and we're seeing it now with Nigeria.

I read about the massacre on the FoxNews ticker at the bottom of the screen last week. I could see why people in Nigeria would be upset that a massacre of 2,000 villagers (in one attack/offensive) gets less attention than an attack in Paris that killed a lot less people. I do recall hearing criticisms that the U.S. State Dept. took so long to officially classify Boko Haram as an international terrorist group (they finally did so in 2013, When Kerry was SecState) despite its record of attacks (mostly bombings of churches, I think), maybe the reason for the delay was that Boko might not be really international. Boko recently got a lot of media attention last year after kidnapping those 200 school girls, but they have been launching attacks for years before (mostly bombings and shootings, but there was also an attack on a boys' school where I think about 50 boys were kidnapped a short while before the famous attack on the girls' school) but those attacks haven't garnered as much attention.
Otherwise I would make the following observations as far as the West goes:

1. Western countries have a moral and legal obligation to prevent their territories or citizens from aiding Boko Haram. This would include going after Boko Haram assets present in their countries, and keeping tabs on citizens or residents within their territory who have ties to Boko and taking steps to prevent them from going to Nigeria (or failing that to inform the Nigerian authorities).

2. Boko Haram is primarily the responsibility of the Nigerians themselves to handle, but the West should offer them some support (equipment, training, advice, financing, etc.), but it is not our role to fight this war for them. We can't just sit around and let innocent people get killed.
3. The West should also offer assistance to neighboring countries to prevent Boko from spreading into those countries.

4. The West also must act strategically. In and of itself, Boko Haram is not a likely threat to Western countries, but it is an organization actuated by an ideology (Jihadism, or Islamic Extremism) which is the biggest external threat currently facing the West, so the West must act. Overall Boko is less of a strategic threat to the West than other similar Salafist groups such as ISIS and the Al Qaeda network (AQ, AQIM, AQAP, etc.). Nonetheless it is a bigger threat than many would suspect at first glance: it is not just launching terror attacks, like ISIS it is seizing territory and could threaten the stability of a state.

This. Instead of waiting for Uncle Sam to roll in with Abrams tanks and M4 carbines, they should at least try and fix their own problems first. Jesus, the US is damned if they do something and damned if they don't. And Nigeria has some scary population growth going on. I've seen stats claiming that if Nigeria keeps growing at the same pace for the next 50-60 years, its population will surpass 700 million and put the US in 4th place for the world's most populous countries; although that might be exaggerated, Nigeria and Africa as a whole are only going to get worse if each woman keeps popping six to eight babies; their food and water sources are scarce and disease is rampant. No one really wants to do much unfortunately because the continent is so politically unstable with several ethnic groups clashing with one another. If it weren't for ridiculously high birth rates, Africa's population would be declining faster than Europe's when disease, malnutrition, and violence kill so many people there.

I also gotta question that graph. First, didn't the industrial revolution begin in the early to mid 1800s? Where there any industrial countries in the 1700s? Also, weren't all countries back then "developing" by our standards? Even in the US, most people were dirt poor during those times.

It refers to nations that are industrialised today and make up what is considered the 1st world. Basically Europe, Japan and the US even if they weren't industrialised at the starting point of the graph. Prior to the 20th century population statistics were a bit of a guessing game anyway as many nations did not have a comprehensive census.
